awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Digital Platform to Assess Water Quality at Urban-Watershed Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to help manage water quality at the boundaries of cities and watersheds.  The proposed work develops a financial system to help cities and public utilities build infrastructure projects. This system integrates physical data with artificial intelligence and advanced monitoring systems. It will serve as a scalable analytics platform using environmental, economic, and social data for financing projects in water quality management.

The proposed project develops analytics and a financial instrument for environmental adaptation and water restoration projects. It uses open-source data management, sensors and interfaces, and mathematical models in a system with state-of-the-art artificial intelligence-enabled digital twin technology. The environmental data will be used in an integrated watershed model using principles of uncertainty analysis and neural network-based learning.   The econometric model combines uncertainty analysis with reinforcement learning where accuracy in prognostics is incentivized.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Supported by the NSF SBIR award, the RESbonds team has achieved its Phase I development objectives for the WaterwAIs project. This project represents a significant leap in water infrastructure planning through the integration of a cloud-based digital twin platform enriched with advanced artificial intelligence capabilities, aimed at addressing the multifaceted environmental and socio-economic challenges associated with urban water infrastructure projects. These water infrastructure projects span the water cycle from wastewater, stormwater and drinking water.  The projects also address events that have occured in the past or that could occur in the future, such as water quality pollution and flood and drought resiience related infrastructure needs. 
WaterwAIs, crafted explicitly for stakeholders in urban watershed pollution and resilience, such as policymakers, urban planners, and utility managers, goes beyond conventional financing models by leveraging predictive or prognostic analytics. This approach enables engagement across a wide array of stakeholders, facilitating equitable investments in water infrastructure.  WaterwAIs links the water projects to its benefits and beneficiaries.  These beneficiaries cieould include watershed properties, tourism or economic activity that improve from the projects.  The analytics predict the benefit from the water infrastructure projects and thus seeks to spread the costs amongst the beneficiaries that go beyond ratepayers.  


Last Modified: 10/15/2024
Modified by: Sudhir N Murthy
